questions.text: A patient who is a diagnosed case of HNPCC, which of the following is the most common repair associated with it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mismatch repair

 

Explanation:

 

Mismatch Repair (MMR) defect leads to Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). This mechanism corrects errors that typically occur during DNA replication. Mutations in MMR genes result in microsatellite instability and contribute to the development of various cancers at an early age. In contrast, Homologous Repair (HR) defects are associated with other genetic disorders and cancers, including Bloom syndrome, Werner syndrome, breast cancer, and Ataxia-Telangiectasia like disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair: Incorrect for this context as it deals with the repair of bulky helix-distorting lesions caused by UV radiation and chemicals, leading to diseases like Xeroderma pigmentosum.

 

Option C. Base excision repair: Incorrect as it fixes small non-helix-distorting bases caused by spontaneous or induced changes, leading to conditions like MUTYH-associated polyposis when defective.

 

Option D. Homologous recombinant repair: Incorrect for HNPCC. It repairs double-strand breaks or interstrand cross-links in DNA, not typically involved in the pathogenesis of HNPCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/pg. 370

choices.text: Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation
Reduced cardiac contractility
Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume
Decreased diastolic perfusion pressure

questions.text: A patient with Prinzmetal angina is administered isosorbide mononitrate and is noticed to have symptomatic relief. What is the mechanism of action of nitrate in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation

 

Nitrates cause endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation when treating Prinzmetal angina.

 

Coronary artery vasospasm is the underlying cause of Prinzmetal angina. By relaxing the smooth muscles of the epicardial coronary arteries, nitrates treat coronary artery spasm.

 

The main mechanism of action of nitrates in the event of stable angina is preferred vein dilation (by increasing cGMP). Venous return to the heart is reduced as a result of venous dilatation (preload). Due to the reduction in ventricular end-diastolic volume, myocardial oxygen consumption also reduces.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduced cardiac contractility: This is not the primary mechanism of action of nitrates in relieving Prinzmetal angina. Nitrates primarily work by vasodilation rather than affecting myocardial contractility.

 

Option C. Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume: Nitrates generally reduce the preload (venous return) by dilating veins, which can lead to a decrease in left ventricular end-diastolic volume, not an increase.

 

Option D. Decreased diastolic perfusion pressure: While nitrates can lower blood pressure, the primary therapeutic effect in Prinzmetal angina is not related to diastolic perfusion pressure but to the direct vasodilation of the coronary arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nitrates provide symptomatic relief in Prinzmetal angina through endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation, which helps to alleviate coronary artery spasms and restore proper blood flow to the heart muscle.

questions.text: Transparency of corneal endothelium is maintained by: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keratan sulphate

 

  • Keratan sulfate is a key glycosaminoglycan present in the corneal endothelium. It plays a significant role in maintaining corneal transparency by regulating hydration, contributing to the structural integrity of the cornea, and preventing swelling, which could impair vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparan sulfate: Heparan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found in the cornea, but its main role is in the basement membrane and Bowman's membrane, rather than the corneal endothelium. It plays a role in supporting the structure but is not the primary factor for endothelial transparency.

 

Option C. Chondroitin sulfate: Chondroitin sulfate is another glycosaminoglycan found in the cornea, but its primary role is not related to endothelial transparency. It contributes to the overall structure and function of the cornea but does not play a direct role in maintaining endothelial clarity.

 

Option D. Hyaluronic acid: Hyaluronic acid is essential for regulating hydration within the cornea, but its main role is in the corneal stroma, not the endothelium. It ensures the cornea remains transparent by preventing excessive swelling in the stromal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 602

questions.text: Identify the acid base disorder in a patient with the following values: pH- 7.2 and pCO2 – 80 mm Hg? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

As pH = 7.2 of the patient’s blood is lower than normal blood pH= 7.35-7.45, so, it’s a case of acidosis. As the acidosis is due to pCO2 = 80 mm of Hg that is higher than normal pCO2 = 35-45 mm of Hg, so, it’s a case of respiratory acidosis rather than metabolic acidosis which occurs due to decreased HCO3- ions.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Metabolic acidosis: This condition is characterized by a decrease in blood pH due to a primary reduction in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not associated with elevated pCO2 levels, which are seen in respiratory acidosis.

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary increase in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not consistent with the low pH and high pCO2 levels seen in the patient.

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary decrease in pCO2 levels, often caused by hyperventilation. It is the opposite of the patient's condition, which shows low pH and high pCO2 levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Respiratory acidosis is indicated by a low blood pH and elevated pCO2 levels, suggesting impaired respiratory function and CO2 retention as the primary cause of the acidosis.

 

Ref: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-15

questions.text: Which of the following organism is intrinsically resistant to the given drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida krusei: Fluconazole

 

  • Candida krusei is known to have intrinsic resistance to fluconazole, which means that this organism generally does not respond to treatment with fluconazole. This is due to a combination of mechanisms including alterations in the target enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, efflux pump activity, and changes in membrane sterols. Therefore, for infections caused by Candida krusei, alternative antifungal agents such as amphotericin B, echinocandins, or voriconazole are typically considered.
  • In the clinical setting, the intrinsic resistance of Candida krusei to fluconazole is significant, as fluconazole is often used as a first-line agent for the treatment of Candida infections. The presence of Candida krusei may therefore necessitate a shift in the standard therapeutic approach and prompt the use of different antifungal therapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus niger: Voriconazole Voriconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that is effective against most species of Aspergillus, including Aspergillus niger. It is often used as a first-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis. Therefore, Aspergillus niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus: Micafungin Aspergillus fumigatus is generally susceptible to micafungin. Micafungin belongs to the echinocandin class of antifungal drugs, which are effective against most Aspergillus species, but echinocandins are not the first choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. They are typically used as second-line agents or in combination therapy for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option C. Candida glabrata: Amphotericin B Candida glabrata can be susceptible to amphotericin B, but it is known for having a dose-dependent sensitivity or a reduced susceptibility. Some strains may show resistance, but this is not considered intrinsic resistance. Instead, amphotericin B resistance in C. glabrata can be due to acquired mechanisms.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, necessitating the use of alternative antifungal agents for treatment.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes this?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Niacin

 

This is Casal’s necklace shown in picture, which occurs in Vitamin B3/ Niacin deficiency. Niacin can be formed in the body from amino acid tryptophan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Thiamine is an essential B-vitamin that plays a crucial role in energy metabolism. It helps the body convert food (carbohydrates) into energy (ATP). Thiamine is important for the proper functioning of nerves and muscles. Deficiency can lead to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which affect the nervous system.

 

Option C. Zinc: Zinc is a trace mineral that is crucial for the immune system, wound healing, and DNA synthesis. It also plays a role in maintaining a sense of taste and smell. Zinc deficiency can lead to impaired immune function, delayed wound healing, and other health issues. It is an essential nutrient for overall health.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine is another B-vitamin that is involved in various metabolic processes, including amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis. It plays a role in maintaining brain health and proper nerve function. Pyridoxine deficiency can lead to symptoms like anemia, nerve damage, and skin issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin is another B-vitamin that is essential for various bodily functions. It plays a role in converting nutrients into energy, creating cholesterol and fats, repairing DNA, and acting as an antioxidant. Niacin is important for overall metabolic health. Severe niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which can have serious effects on the skin, digestive system, and nervous system.

 

Niacin deficiency can be caused by:

  • Dietary deficiency of tryptophan
  • Dietary deficiency Vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency
  • Carcinoid syndrome
  • Hartnup’s disease

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical features can be encountered in Korsakoff psychosis? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Amnesia
  2. Confabulation
  3. Ophthalmoplegia
  4. Peripheral neuropathy
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 4

 

Korsakoff psychosis, or Korsakoff syndrome, is a chronic neuropsychiatric syndrome resulting from chronic deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1), commonly associated with chronic alcoholism. It is often considered an irreversible condition, unlike its acute counterpart, Wernicke's encephalopathy, which can be treated with thiamine supplementation.

 

Clinical Features of Korsakoff Psychosis:

 

1. Amnesia: Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by severe memory impairment, both anterograde (inability to form new memories) and retrograde (loss of previously formed memories) amnesia. Long-term memory, however, tends to remain relatively intact.

 

2. Confabulation: Patients often exhibit confabulation, where they fabricate stories to fill gaps in their memory. This is not intentional lying but a way to compensate for memory loss.

 

4. Peripheral Neuropathy: Chronic alcoholics often suffer from peripheral neuropathy due to thiamine deficiency and direct neurotoxic effects of alcohol. This neuropathy involves the axons of peripheral nerves and manifests as numbness, tingling, and pain in the extremities.

 

Other Option:

 

Not a Feature of Korsakoff Psychosis:

 

3. Ophthalmoplegia: This is a feature of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which presents acutely with a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion. Ophthalmoplegia refers to paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles. It is reversible with thiamine treatment and is not typically seen in the chronic phase of Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff psychosis is characterized by severe memory impairment (amnesia), confabulation, and peripheral neuropathy. It does not include ophthalmoplegia, which is a feature of the acute Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: What is the causative organism for the condition shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

The given image shows a hydatid cyst in the liver. Large, unilocular/multilocular, well-defined, hypodense cysts. Contains multiple internal “daughter” cysts of lower density than “mother” cyst (exocyst). Curvilinear ring-like calcification of pericyst (wall).

 

Causative organism – Echinococcus granulosus

 

Definitive hosts – Dogs, Intermediate host – Sheep, Accidental intermediate host – Human (end stage host)

 

In the liver, the pressure effect of the cyst can produce symptoms of obstructive jaundice and abdominal pain. With biliary rupture, the classic triad of biliary colic, jaundice, and urticaria is observed. Passage of hydatid membranes in the emesis (hydatid emesia) and passage of membranes in the stools (hydatid enterica) may occur rarely.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schistosoma japonicum: This parasitic worm causes schistosomiasis, primarily affecting the intestines and liver, but it does not form hydatid cysts.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cruzi: This protozoan parasite causes Chagas disease, which primarily affects the heart and digestive system, not forming cysts in the liver.

 

Option D. Schistosoma mansoni: This parasitic worm also causes schistosomiasis, affecting the intestines and liver, but it does not form hydatid cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The condition shown in the image, characterized by a hydatid cyst in the liver, is caused by Echinococcus granulosus. The cysts contain internal daughter cysts and can lead to symptoms related to the pressure effect on the liver and biliary system.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with a satellite skin lesion. On examination, the patient has one hypopigmented lesion and one thickened nerve. The images of two blister packs are provided. Based on the WHO / NLEP Guidelines, which treatment is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer:

The correct answer is B. Packet 2 for 12 months.

Latest Guidelines for Leprosy: NLEP = WHO (from April 1, 2025)

As of April 1, 2025, India's NLEP has aligned completely with WHO guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of leprosy. This means that the same criteria and drug regimens are now followed globally and in India.

 

*If a case has any one of the three features suggestive of MB, he/she is classified as MB.

 

Treatment Regimen: WHO & NLEP (Post April 1st 2025)

 

Other Options:

Option A: Packet 1 for 12 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option C: Packet 1 for 6 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option D Packet 2 for 6 months: 

Although Packet 2 contains the correct medications, the treatment duration of 6 months is insufficient for multibacillary leprosy according to WHO guidelines, which recommends 12 months.

 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to diagnose Leprosy 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to treat Leprosy 

OLD PB MDT with 2 drugs followed by NLEP:

 

Educational objective:

  • As of April 1, 2025, NLEP follows WHO guidelines for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • Classification is based on skin lesions, nerve involvement, and skin smear.
  • For a patient with multibacillary leprosy, characterized by one or more thickened nerves and multiple skin lesions, the appropriate treatment is with a regimen containing rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone (Packet 2) for a duration of 12 months.

 

References:

Jopling’s handbook of leprosy, 6th edition, page no 10

Andrew’s diseases of the skin: clinical dermatology 13th edition page no 338, 339, 345

questions.text: A child is presented with multiple times loose stools. He is managed with ORS. Glucose in ORS is absorbed via which transporter in GIT?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SGLT-1

 

Sodium-Glucose Transporter 1

 

  • SGLT-1 is a transporter protein located in the small intestine. It plays a crucial role in the absorption of glucose and sodium from the gut lumen into the enterocytes (intestinal cells). In the context of ORS, SGLT-1 facilitates the absorption of glucose, which helps in the rehydration process by increasing fluid absorption.

 

Glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestinal lumen into intestinal cell via secondary active transport using sodium dependent glucose transporter (SGLT-1). On the other hand, the glucose from the intestine cell in to blood at basolateral membrane is transported via passive transporter GLUT-2 (see fig)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT-2 (Sodium-Glucose Transporter 2): SGLT-2 is primarily found in the proximal renal tubules of the kidney and is responsible for the reabsorption of glucose from the urine. It is not involved in the absorption of glucose from the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. GLUT-4 (Glucose Transporter 4): GLUT-4 is a glucose transporter primarily found in muscle and adipose tissue. It is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake into these tissues and is not related to glucose absorption in the gut.

 

Option D. GLUT-2 (Glucose Transporter 2): GLUT-2 is a glucose transporter found in the liver, pancreatic beta cells, and the basolateral membrane of enterocytes. It is involved in glucose uptake by the liver and pancreas and is not the primary transporter for glucose absorption in the gut.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT-1 is the key transporter responsible for the absorption of glucose in the gastrointestinal tract. This mechanism is crucial in the management of conditions like diarrhea, where ORS containing glucose can help rehydrate the body by enhancing fluid absorption.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 538

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with bleeding disorder, gives family history of her father and sister suffering from the same bleeding disorders. Which is the most likely disorder? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease is a common inherited bleeding disorder that affects both males and females, and it is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that males and females have an equal chance of inheriting the disorder from a parent, which is consistent with the family history provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilia A: This is a X-linked recessive disorder primarily affecting males; females are typically carriers unless under rare circumstances.

 

Option C. Christmas Disease (Hemophilia B): Similar to Hemophilia A, this condition is also X-linked recessive, predominantly affecting males.

 

Option D. Factor 12 Deficiency: This is a much rarer condition and usually does not lead to significant bleeding issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand disease is characterized by its autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and affects both genders, making it the most likely diagnosis for a female patient with a family history of bleeding disorders involving both male and female family members.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that passes through the marked foramen marked 2 in the image below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Oculomotor nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The marked structure is the superior orbital fissure and the oculomotor nerve passes through this fissure.

 

Superior orbital fissure is divided into three compartments by the common tendinous ring. The oculomotor nerve passes through its intermediate compartment.

 

 

The oculomotor nerve primarily controls the movements of several eye muscles, including the levator palpebrae superioris (lifts the upper eyelid), and the superior, inferior, and medial rectus muscles, which control eye movements. It also controls the constriction of the pupil (miosis) and accommodation of the lens for near vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Olfactory Nerve (CN I):

 

  • The olfactory nerve originates from the olfactory bulbs, which are extensions of the brain, located on the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone within the anterior cranial fossa.

 

  • The olfactory nerve is responsible for the sense of smell. It carries sensory information related to odors from the nasal cavity to the olfactory bulbs.

 

Option C. Optic Nerve (CN II):

 

  • The optic nerve emerges from the optic canal, which is located in the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone within the middle cranial fossa.

 

  • The optic nerve is crucial for vision. It transmits visual information from the retina to the brain, allowing us to perceive and interpret visual stimuli.

 

Option D. Facial Nerve (CN VII):

 

  • The facial nerve emerge from a stylomastoid foramen from the base of the skull.

 

  • It controls the muscles of facial expression, taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and the production of saliva and tears. It also carries sensory information related to taste.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Cherry red spots on retina and mental retardation is seen in: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tay Sach’s disease

 

This is the correct answer. Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by cherry red spots on the retina, which are a distinctive sign of the condition. It is also associated with mental retardation and neurological symptoms. Tay-Sachs is a rare genetic disorder that affects the central nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher's Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a typical feature of Gaucher's disease. Gaucher's disease primarily affects the spleen, liver, and bone marrow, leading to symptoms such as anemia, enlarged liver and spleen, and bone pain.

 

Option C. Hunter Syndrome: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a common feature of Hunter syndrome. Hunter syndrome primarily affects connective tissues and leads to symptoms such as joint stiffness and organ enlargement.

 

Option D. Krabbe’s Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not typically seen in Krabbe disease. Krabbe disease is a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and leads to symptoms like muscle weakness and developmental delay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark feature of Tay-Sachs disease is the presence of "cherry red spots" on the retina of the eye. These spots are a distinctive sign observed during eye examinations. Additionally, individuals with Tay-Sachs disease often experience progressive neurological deterioration, including muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures. There is also a characteristic decline in cognitive function, leading to intellectual and developmental disability.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation were done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroid irrigation and antihistamines

 

The history of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip with endoscopy findings of mucosal edema suggests the presence of acute rhinosinusitis. The next best management involves nasal steroid irrigation along with antihistamines to reduce the mucosal inflammation, congestion, and edema. Even though the patient underwent FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery) 5 years ago, the patent ostia indicate that the surgery was successful in creating drainage pathways, but inflammation persists.

 

Acute viral rhinosinusitis often leads to mucosal edema, which can obstruct the sinus ostia and impair mucociliary clearance, causing symptoms like headache, facial pain, and nasal congestion. Steroid irrigation and antihistamines are used to reduce this inflammation and promote drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat surgery: Repeat surgery is not indicated because the DNE (Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy) findings show patent ostia, indicating no structural blockage requiring surgical correction. Surgery is reserved for patients with failed medical management or irreversible anatomical issues.

 

Option B. Macrolides for 4 months: Macrolides (such as azithromycin) are not routinely used for long-term management of rhinosinusitis unless there is chronic bacterial infection or the patient shows signs of immune deficiency. In this case, no bacterial infection is present, and there are no signs of infection requiring antibiotics.

 

Option D. Biological therapy: Biological therapies (e.g., monoclonal antibodies) are considered in refractory chronic sinusitis with polyps, especially when associated with conditions like asthma. However, they are not standard treatments for uncomplicated rhinosinusitis with mucosal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal steroid irrigation and antihistamines are the next best step in the management of acute rhinosinusitis with mucosal edema and patent sinus ostia, especially in patients with previous sinus surgery. This approach reduces inflammation and edema to restore normal sinus drainage.

questions.text: Methylisothiazolinone (MI) in cosmetics is used as? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preservative

 

Methylisothiazolinone (MIT) is a preservative present in various facial cosmetics, deodorants, sunscreens, and industrial products. The frequency of contact dermatitis resulting from either Methyl-chloro-isothiazolinone/methylisothiazolinone (MCI/MIT or Kathon CG) or MIT has been on the rise.

 

 

Moreover, there have been reported cases of severe airborne and generalized dermatitis caused by exposure to MIT through recently painted walls and even from toilet cleaners.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

It's important to understand that Methylisothiazolinone (MI) is used as a preservative in cosmetics to prevent microbial growth, distinguishing it from surfactants, humectants, and emulsifiers, which have different functional roles in product formulation.

 

Ref:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 128, Page no 128.36

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4689087/

questions.text: A person presented with neurological manifestations mimicking UMN (Upper Motor Neuron) palsy and sensory neuropathy. The patient was pale and investigations revealed anemia. The probable micronutrient deficiency is? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

The neurological manifestations mimicking Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) palsy and sensory neuropathy, along with the presence of anemia, suggest a possible vitamin B12 deficiency. It can cause a type of anemia known as megaloblastic anemia, which can present with pale skin. Moreover, B12 deficiency can also lead to neurological symptoms such as UMN palsy and sensory neuropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B9 (Folate): Folate deficiency can lead to anemia, but it is not typically associated with neurological manifestations resembling UMN palsy and sensory neuropathy.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Niacin deficiency can cause pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While it involves neurological symptoms, it doesn't typically mimic UMN palsy.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Thiamine deficiency can cause beriberi, a condition that primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems. However, it is not typically associated with symptoms mimicking UMN palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to a variety of neurological symptoms, including UMN-like signs and sensory neuropathy, due to its essential role in nerve function. This deficiency can result from dietary inadequacy or malabsorption, leading to anemia and neurological complications. It's crucial to recognize the clinical presentation of vitamin B12 deficiency to provide appropriate treatment and prevent long-term neurological damage.

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyanide

 

Explanation:


Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.

 

Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.

 

Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: FAD status in body is determined by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione reductase

 

This is the correct answer. Glutathione reductase is an enzyme that contains FAD as a prosthetic group and plays a significant role in the reduction of glutathione disulfide (GSSG) to glutathione (GSH). The activity of glutathione reductase, which depends on the availability of FAD, can be used to assess tissue riboflavin (FAD precursor) status. Therefore, measuring the activity of glutathione reductase with and without FAD is a method for assessing FAD status in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is not directly involved in determining FAD status. Thiamine plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism but doesn't directly influence the levels of FAD in the body.

 

Option C. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is an enzyme involved in the first step of glucose metabolism, but it is not responsible for determining FAD status.

 

Option D. Transketolase: Transketolase is marker enzyme for B1 deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FAD is the active form of Vitamin B2 and marker for the B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity as this enzyme require B2 as coenzyme. So, in case of FAD deficiency, glutathione reductase activity will be lowered without affecting the quantity of enzyme.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 534

questions.text: In an isolated mitochondria, in a medium containing Succinate, Fumarate, ADP and Pi, ATPs were produced. Later a compound was added, and oxidative phosphorylation was decreased. What’s that compound? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oligomycin

 

  • Oligomycin is an antibiotic that inhibits ATP synthase, a key enzyme complex in oxidative phosphorylation. It blocks the flow of protons (H+) through ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis. As a result, adding oligomycin would indeed decrease oxidative phosphorylation, leading to a reduction in ATP production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP): 2,4-dinitrophenol is a chemical uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation. It disrupts the proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane, making it leaky to protons. This uncoupling reduces the efficiency of ATP production but doesn't directly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option C. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It blocks the transfer of electrons from ubiquinone to cytochrome c, disrupting the electron flow in the chain.

 

Option D. Rotenone: Rotenone is an inhibitor of complex I in the electron transport chain. It prevents the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone, disrupting electron flow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligomycin specifically targets ATP synthase and inhibits ATP synthesis in oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, the compound that was added to the isolated mitochondria, leading to a decrease in oxidative phosphorylation

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 123

questions.text:
First part of PCT has which of the following transport proteins? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Sodium potassium pump
  2. Na- glucose co-transporter
  3. Sodium hydrogen antiport
  4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1,2,3

 

1. Sodium-potassium pump: This transporter is found on the basolateral side of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) cells and is critical for maintaining the sodium gradient that drives other transport processes.

 

2. Na-glucose co-transporter: This is located on the apical membrane of PCT cells and uses the sodium gradient to co-transport glucose from the tubular lumen into the cell.

 

3. Sodium-hydrogen antiport: Also on the apical membrane, this antiporter exchanges sodium from the tubular lumen with hydrogen ions from the cell, playing a key role in sodium reabsorption and pH balance.

 

Other Option

 

4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter: It is present in the distal or late part of PCT (Not in the early PCT)- contributes to bicarbonate reabsorption.

The correct combination based on the provided answer is b) 1,2,3, which includes the sodium-potassium pump, the Na-glucose co-transporter, and the sodium-hydrogen antiport, all of which are essential for the function of the PCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proximal convoluted tubule – transport processes –

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient was brought to the ER after RTA, her RR is 22/min, BP is 90/60mmHg. On examination, hyper-resonance is heard over the right side of the chest. The chest X-ray performed is given below. What would be the appropriate management in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

 

The given scenario of tachypnea, hypotension, hyper-resonance and x ray showing absent right broncho-vascular markings is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

This option correctly addresses the likely diagnosis of a pneumothorax. The initial needle insertion can decompress the tension pneumothorax, and subsequent placement of an intercostal drain allows for continuous drainage of pleural air or fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS: This option suggests inserting a needle into the 5th ICS to relieve tension pneumothorax, which can occur due to trauma. While this can be a life-saving procedure, the presence of hyper-resonance on examination suggests a pneumothorax, but it does not address the drainage of pleural fluid, which is the primary concern in this case.

 

Option C. Aspiration of the pleural fluid: Aspiration of pleural fluid may be indicated in cases of pleural effusion, but it does not address the likely pneumothorax seen in this patient's presentation.

 

Option D. No intervention needed: With the patient's clinical presentation, including respiratory distress, low blood pressure, and hyper-resonance, intervention is indeed needed. Failure to intervene could lead to worsening respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening consequences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tension pneumothorax usually occurs due to trauma, such as a rib fracture, a puncture wound, or chest surgery, but it can also develop spontaneously in patients with underlying lung diseases, such as emphysema or cystic fibrosis.
  • Immediate treatment of tension pneumothorax is essential to prevent respiratory and cardiac arrest. The first step is to perform needle decompression, which involves inserting a large-bore needle into the affected side of the chest to release the trapped air in the triangle of safety. After that, a chest tube is inserted to further drain the air and prevent the reoccurrence of a pneumothorax.

questions.text: Which extracellular cell adhesion is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occludens

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae disrupts occludens, specifically targeting tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, which impairs their barrier function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrin: Primarily involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, not typically disrupted by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option B. Cadherin: Important for cell-cell adhesion in adherens junctions, not the main target of Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as occludens are indeed affected by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio cholerae specifically targets occludens, which are crucial components of tight junctions, thereby compromising intestinal epithelial barrier functions.

questions.text: A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate show the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?(NEET  PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical vignette of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance points to diagnosis of Gaucher's disease, in which enzyme deficient is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher’s Disease

questions.text: A woman on anti-depressants presents with bleeding. She gives a history of bulky stools which sticks to the pan. Which of the following vitamin deficiency can cause bleeding in this condition?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin K

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, and its deficiency can lead to a bleeding tendency. Bulky stools that stick to the pan can be indicative of malabsorption issues, which could result in inadequate absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including Vitamin K. This deficiency can lead to bleeding problems.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not typically associated with bleeding disorders but can lead to other health issues, including vision problems.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can result in various symptoms, but it is not known to directly cause bleeding disorders.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency may lead to neurological and muscle problems but is not a common cause of bleeding disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulky, greasy stools that stick to the pan (often described as "steatorrhea") can be indicative of malabsorption, a condition where the absorption of nutrients, including fat-soluble vitamins, is impaired. Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.

 

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.Top of Form

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 532

questions.text: The following histological image is seen in the patient who is complaining of growth failure and abdominal distension.  Signs found were anemia, thrombocytopenia and bony pain. Which enzyme is deficient in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta-Glucocerebroside

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a crumpled tissue paper appearance of cell which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. It is a sphingolipidoses and the most common lysosomal storage disease and occur due to deficiency of lysosomal enzyme β-glucocerebrosidase. The substrate glucosylceramide gets accumulated in macrophages causing eccentric nucleus.

Other clinical features are: Bony pain, pathological fracture, hepatosplenomegaly but no mental retardation (as beta-glucosylceramide is not present in brain).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphingomyelinase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Niemann-Pick disease, characterized by the accumulation of sphingomyelin in macrophages. Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, progressive neurodegeneration, and the presence of foam cells. Niemann-Pick disease often presents with mental retardation.

 

Option C. Hexosaminidase: This enzyme has two forms, A and B. Deficiency of Hexosaminidase A leads to Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside, primarily affecting neurons. Clinical features include progressive neurodegeneration, a cherry-red spot on the macula, and early death. Deficiency of both Hexosaminidase A and B leads to Sandhoff disease, which presents similarly to Tay-Sachs but with additional visceral involvement.

 

Option D. G-6-phosphatase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Von Gierke’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I), characterized by impaired glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Clinical features include severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. Patients often present with a doll-like facies, protuberant abdomen, and growth retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher’s Disease

 

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: Which of the following has autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystic fibrosis

 

Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means that an individual needs to inherit two copies of the altered gene (one from each parent) to manifest the condition.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Achondroplasia: Achondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that having one copy of the altered gene is sufficient to express the condition.

 

Option B. Huntington’s disease: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern as well, where one copy of the altered gene is enough to cause the disease.

 

Option D. Familial Hypercholesterolemia: Familial Hypercholesterolemia is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, but there are rare cases of autosomal recessive inheritance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AD (Autosomal Dominant)                                                                                       

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia
  • Huntington's disease
  • Lactose Intolerance
  • Marfan Syndrome
  • Myotonic Dystrophy
  • AD Polycystic Kidney Disease
  • Porphyria Variegate

 

AR (Autosomal Recessive)

  • Ataxia Telangiectasia
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Familial Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
  • Sickle Cell disease
  • Thalassemia
  • Maple Syrup Urine disease
  • Homocystinuria
  • Alkaptonuria
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Albinism
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Wilson's disease
  • Hemochromatosis
  • AR Polycystic Kidney disease
  • Orotic Aciduria
  • Glycogen Storage Diseases
  • All Mucopolysaccharidosis (except Hunter’s)
  • All sphingolipidosis except Fabry’s disease

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 478

questions.text: Identify the given condition: (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Given histology image shows a suprabasal blister which points to a diagnosis of Pemphigus Vulgaris.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leprosy: Tuberculoid leprosy (paucibacillary) will show granulomatous lesions while lepromatous lesions (multibacillary) shows lipid-laden macrophages (lepra cells) filled with masses (globi) of acid-fast bacilli.

 

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides: Lower portion of the epidermis contains hyperchromatic enlarged lymphocytes. Pautrier’s microabscesses may be seen which are intradermal clusters of atypical lymphoid cells.

 

 

Option D. Visceral Leishmaniasis: Visceral Leishmaniasis shows skin lesion with abundant amastigotes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by suprabasal blisters and a row of tombstone appearance on histology, with a fishnet pattern on direct immunofluorescence due to IgG deposition.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 2307-2308

choices.text: Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

questions.text: All of the following is true regarding scrub typhus except: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

 

Causative organism – Orientia tsutsugamushi (an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium).

 

They cannot grow on cell free media. They are readily cultivated in yolk sac of developing chick embryos. They also grow on mouse fibroblast, HeLa, Hep-2, Detroit 6 and other continuous cell lines.

 

Vector - Infected chiggers (trombiculid mite larvae).

 

Host: A number of small rodents particularly wild rats of subgenus Rattus are the natural hosts for scrub typhus. Human infection takes place when man accidentally picks up an infective larval mite while walking, sitting, or lying on the infested ground.

 

The adult mites have a four-stage lifecycle: egg, larva, nymph and adult.

 

The larva is the only stage (chigger) that can transmit the disease to humans and other vertebrates, since the other life stages (nymph and adult) do not feed on vertebrate animals. Both the nymph and the adult are free-living in the soil.

 

Signs and Symptoms- Fever and chills, Headache, Body aches and muscle pain. Dark, scab-like region at the site of the chigger bite (also known as eschar). Mental changes, ranging from confusion to coma. Enlarged lymph nodes and rash are also seen.

 

Diagnosis of scrub typhus that includes enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), immunofluorescence assay (IFA), immunochromatographic test (ICT), Weil–Felix, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transmitted by chiggers: This is true. Scrub typhus is transmitted by the larvae (chiggers) of trombiculid mites.

 

Option B. Lymphadenopathy is a feature: This is true. Enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) are a common feature of scrub typhus.

 

Option D. Man is an accidental host: This is true. Humans are accidental hosts who become infected when they come into contact with infected chiggers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is an obligate intracellular bacterium that cannot grow on cell-free media like MacConkey agar. It requires living cells for its cultivation. Scrub typhus is transmitted by chiggers and features symptoms such as fever, lymphadenopathy, and a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite. Humans are accidental hosts for this infection.

choices.text: Age, sex, cough, chronic diarrhea

questions.text: A 68-year-old lady was brought to the hospital by her daughter, with episodes of falls, confusion, chronic diarrhea, and cough. The intern decided to conduct a geriatric assessment. Which of the following factors indicated such an examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Age, fall, confusion.

 

This patient's age, history of falls, and episodes of confusion necessitate a comprehensive geriatric assessment. Falls and cognitive impairment are major indicators of declining functional status in older adults, and age is a key factor in determining the need for such assessments.

 

Comprehensive geriatric assessments include:

 

  • Age: Elderly patients are at increased risk of physical and cognitive decline.
  • History of falls: Falls indicate mobility issues, potential frailty, or balance problems.
  • Cognitive changes like confusion: This may be indicative of underlying neurological issues, delirium, or dementia, warranting a detailed evaluation.

 

Such an assessment helps address potential physical, cognitive, and psychosocial issues, providing a holistic plan for the patient's care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age, sex, falls: While age and falls are relevant, sex alone is not a specific indicator for a geriatric assessment. Confusion and cognitive changes carry more significance.

 

Option B. Age, cough, chronic diarrhoea: Cough and chronic diarrhea are not primary indicators for a geriatric assessment. These symptoms may require a focused clinical evaluation but do not necessitate a comprehensive geriatric assessment.

 

Option D. Age, sex, cough, chronic diarrhea: Similar to Option B, while age is relevant, the combination of symptoms here does not directly indicate the need for a geriatric assessment, as the presence of falls and confusion would.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The need for a comprehensive geriatric assessment is primarily indicated by age, history of falls, and cognitive changes (e.g., confusion), as these factors significantly impact the physical and mental well-being of older adults.

questions.text: A drug used to treat Tinea cruris that is experiencing an increasing development of widespread resistance is? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Terbinafine

 

  • Terbinafine is an antifungal used to treat Tinea cruris ("Jock/Dhobi itch").
  • Tinea cruris is typically caused by the fungus Trichophyton rubrum.
  • Effectiveness of terbinafine is compromised due to increasing resistance, especially in chronic or recurrent infections.
  • Resistance to terbinafine is associated with mutations in the squalene epoxidase gene, diminishing the drug’s efficacy.

 

 

  • Squalene epoxidase is vital for ergosterol synthesis, crucial for the fungal cell membrane.
  • Terbinafine-resistant fungal strains are cross-resistant to other squalene epoxidase inhibitors.

 

NOTE: Despite resistance to terbinafine, these strains remain sensitive to azoles and other antifungal classes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole:

 

  • While Itraconazole is effective against dermatophytoses, but there's no specific indication of increasing resistance against it in the context of Tinea cruris.
  • Mechanism of Action: Itraconazole inhibits the enzyme cytochrome P450 14α-demethylase, which is necessary for the conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane. This leads to accumulation of toxic intermediates and membrane dysfunction.

 

Option B. Griseofulvin:

 

  • This drug is used for treatment, but there's no specific indication of increasing resistance against it in the context of Tinea cruris.
  • Mechanism of Action: Griseofulvin binds to tubulin, disrupting the microtubule function and thereby inhibiting mitosis in fungal cells. It specifically targets dividing fungal cells.

 

Option D. Voriconazole:

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Similar to Itraconazole, Voriconazole also inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme involved in the production of ergosterol for the fungal cell membrane.
  • It has a broad spectrum of antifungal activity. But it is not routinely used for treating superficial fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terbinafine is increasingly encountering resistance in the treatment of Tinea cruris, likely due to mutations in the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase, which is the drug's target.
